dataset.title: Data to explore circular manureshed management in beef supply chains of the United States and western Canada

address.deliveryPoint: P.O. Box 30003; MSC 3JER New Mexico State University

creator.organizationName: USDA-ARS, Pasture Systems and Watershed Mgmnt
USDA-ARS, Soil Mgmt and Sugar Beet Research Unit

address.deliveryPoint: P.O. Box 30003, MSC 3JER New Mexico State University

abstract.para: Circular management of beef supply chains holds great promise for improving sustainability from grazing agroecosystem to dinner plate. In the United States and Canada, one approach to circularity entails transporting manure nutrients from cattle produced in feedlots back to the grazing agroecosystems where they originated to enrich haylands for further grazing cattle production. We provide data to assess this strategy centered around three grazing agroecosystems: Florida, New Mexico, and the provincial assemblage of Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta, British Columbia. We describe four datasets that can be used to estimate the potential nutrient utilization of hay fed to grazing cattle in the three grazing agroecosystems and the magnitudes of feedlot manure nutrients available for transport back to them. We found that although biogeography and management differ among the three grazing agroecosystems, the hay allocated for grazing cattle represented approximately 65% of the total harvested hay produced per agroecosystem after accounting for harvest losses, and that on average all three areas exported about 450,000 cattle annually for feedlot, pasture, and slaughter to states across the US. Although we highlight only three grazingland settings, our approach relies on methods that could ultimately be scaled nationally and internationally, with applicability to other animal industries for which circular management is an aspiration for sustainability outcomes.

keywordSet.keywordThesaurus: USDA National Ag Library's Agricultural Thesaurus

intellectualRights.para: This information is released under the Creative Commons license - Attribution - CC BY (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/). The consumer of these data ("Data User" herein) is required to cite it appropriately in any publication that results from its use. The Data User should realize that these data may be actively used by others for ongoing research and that coordination may be necessary to prevent duplicate publication. The Data User is urged to contact the authors of these data if any questions about methodology or results occur. Where appropriate, the Data User is encouraged to consider collaboration or co-authorship with the authors. The Data User should realize that misinterpretation of data may occur if used out of context of the original study. While substantial efforts are made to ensure the accuracy of data and associated documentation, complete accuracy of data sets cannot be guaranteed. All data are made available "as is." The Data User should be aware, however, that data are updated periodically and it is the responsibility of the Data User to check for new versions of the data. The data authors and the repository where these data were obtained shall not be liable for damages resulting from any use or misinterpretation of the data. Thank you.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Florida: Bounding box for the state of Florida.
New Mexico: Bounding box for the state of New Mexico
western Canada: Bounding box for the four southwestern provinces of western Canada: Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta, British Columbia

address.deliveryPoint: P.O. Box 30003, MSC 3JER New Mexico State University

description.para: We acquired data from disparate sources including national agricultural surveys and brand inspection records from state agencies. We processed the data using original routines to estimate the amount of harvested forages used to supplement grazing cattle in three grazing-oriented agroecosystems, the nutrient demands of that harvested forage, and the manure nutrients produced in feedlots by the cattle that originated from the agroecosystems. We then aggregated the processed data and made them available to allow others to use. Those efforts resulted in four published datasets: 1. Dataset 1: Hay intake by grazing cattle in three grazing agroecosystems, 2. Dataset 2: Potential nutrient removal by hay fed to grazing cattle in the three grazing agroecosystems, 3. Dataset 3: Cattle flows from the three grazing agroecosystems to feedlots, and 4. Dataset 4: Feedlot manure nutrients from cattle originating from the three grazing agroecosystems.

We focused on cattle and manure flows originating in the US states of New Mexico and Florida, and an assemblage of the four westernmost Canadian provinces (Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta, British Columbia) due to the social and economic importance of grazingland production systems in those agroecosystems, as well as their tendencies to export cattle from grazinglands to feedlots that are geographically distant (Shields and Mathews 2003; Buhnerkempe et al.¬†2013; Sheppard et al., 2015). We treat the four westernmost provinces in Canada as a cohesive provincial assemblage because of the structure of data available from Canadian sources.
A more detailed description of the methods can be found in the dataset paper: [paper under review]

section.para: The Jornada Experimental Range Long-Term Agroecosystems Research (LTAR) program is part of a national network of long-term agricultural and rangeland ecology research sites funded by the US Department of Agriculture (USDA). The Jornada Experimental Range is administered by the USDA-ARS (USDA Agricultural Research Service).
The Jornada Experimental Range is supported by the USDA Long-Term Agroecosystem Research Network (CRIS# 3050-11210-009-00D)
